function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Hospital isolation measures were effective in reducing the number of infected humans but had a small effect on the arrival time of the maximum number of infected humans and the duration of the COVID-19 outbreak.","Impact":"Potential rapid spread of the disease when medical beds reach capacity, leading to a similar scale of outbreak as the original infectious state.","Mitigation":"Developing additional capacity for medical beds and resources to meet the potential surge in infected patients.","Technologies":"Advanced hospital management systems for efficient resource allocation and patient care.","People":"Patients, healthcare workers, and the general public in areas with limited medical resources.","Owner":"Healthcare institutions, government health departments, and policymakers."},{"Description":"Self-protection measures were effective in reducing the number of infected humans and delaying the arrival of the peak number of infected humans, but had little effect under stricter quarantine measures.","Impact":"Reduced effectiveness of self-protection measures under stricter quarantine, leading to increased risk of infection.","Mitigation":"Focusing on strict enforcement of quarantine measures and resource allocation to support self-protection efforts in less stringent quarantine scenarios.","Technologies":"Public health surveillance systems, remote monitoring, and enforcement technologies for quarantine compliance.","People":"General public, individuals in quarantine, and enforcement agencies.","Owner":"Government health departments, public health organizations, and law enforcement agencies."},{"Description":"The study analyzed the impact of quarantine, self-protection, and hospital isolation measures to slow the spread of COVID-19, with high interpretability and geographical mapping of model parameters for practical intervention significance.","Impact":"Improved understanding of the effectiveness of intervention measures and ability to tailor specific epidemic prevention and control decisions based on geographic data.","Mitigation":"Integration of study findings into public health policy and resource allocation for targeted intervention strategies.","Technologies":"Geographical information systems (GIS), data analysis tools, and modeling software for simulation and visualization of epidemic spread.","People":"Epidemiologists, public health officials, policymakers, and government health departments.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations, and government health departments."}]}
